One of the common contingencies to real estate purchase agreements is a home inspection. Hired by the buyer, an inspector examines the house thoroughly for non-functioning systems, damages, and repairs that may be needed.

What does a home inspector do? Home inspectors look at the interior and exterior of your home and provide you a general understanding of the “condition” of the home. They will assess for you the general condition of the roof, gutters, foundation, electrical system, plumbing system, and HVAC system.

Brand new condominiums are subject to different home inspections as part of the closing process. If you bought a condominium from a builder, you will take part in a Pre-delivery Inspection (PDI) – you can read more about the PDI on the Tarion website.
